Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?! is a casual management game from Daylight Studios. Your Grandfather has sadly passed away and he has left you his 0.01% stake in his blacksmith business, you feel you have no choice but to carry on his work and with the help of Agent 46 you try to create the most successful blacksmithing business the world has ever seen! Manage the shop, research new weapons, train up and coming blacksmiths, craft weapons for the World's heroes and so much more, all with the repeated click of a button (you have to do a lot of clicking).

Before I get underway I'd briefly like to mention my first impressions of the game. For the first half an hour or so I really did not like this game at all, it was a tutorial section so nothing was really unlocked yet and it just felt so tedious, click here, click there, make money etc. Thankfully, once more stuff became unlocked, I began to enjoy the game more, to the point where I played it for 4 hours straight. Sadly the game receeds into tedium later on, but more on that later.

+Charming art style
+Good writing and loads of amusing references to other games, movies and music
+A huge number of weapons, of many different types, to research and craft
+Occasionally random events will occur (such as a potato is struggling to cut a sapling down. Help him?) which provide a somewhat interesting break from the main game though this do begin to get repetitive rather quickly
+Most things, from your name to the name's of your weapons, can be named which can be rather amusing if you're good at coming up with funny names
+Nice, relaxing music, which fits well with the game
+The game gives you objectives to complete which helps guide you through the game
+You can upgrade your shop with cosmetic items such as carpets, wallpapers, dog houses etc

+/-The game's UI makes it feel like a mobile game, despite the fact that it's not, probably due to the dev studio mainly working on mobile games. Personally, I don't really mind this but I know it may bother some people

-There's next to no gameplay depth, all it is is researching weapons, followed by sending someone to buy supplies, followed by telling your blacksmiths to craft the weapon and you have to do this again and again and again and again
-For a good few hours the game is pretty interesting, the objectives are still pretty small so they don't take long to complete hence the game flows quickly but once you get into the later stages of the game selling three weapons (the most you can do in one go) only pushes the objective up by around 3% which means you have to grind out the same weapons over and over again which gets incredibly boring (this is the very reason I stopped playing the game)
-Some of the dialogue between your character and Agent 46 is repeated several times which I thought was pretty lazy
-So. Much. Clicking. I've never gotten into any of the clicker games so having to click so much in this game was rather irritating
-No graphical options, no control options and only very basic audio options

Verdict:
Worth Purchasing on Sale (6.5/10)

Holy Potatoes! is a fun, casual management game, with a charming art style and funny references, for a time before quickly descending into tedium. Even fans of management games will find this game quickly gets repetitive so only buy it if you see it on sale or you really can't help yourself.

Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?! is a game about running a weapons store/blacksmith in an RPG universe filled with...Potatoes

The world seems cute, loaded with potato puns along with simple yet good graphics, but with only a few things to do in it no amount of looking pretty and cute dialogue is going to redeem the fact that in its essence it's a waiting game.

That's right, there's no real simulation or management here(Thanks steam tags!), with you just sending your potatoes out to do things and then waiting for them to come back. Or alternatively, telling them to make a weapon and then waiting for them to finish. The large part of this game is waiting for things to be done so that you can tell them to do more things...And then you wait some more.
This may be fine and well for a timewaster game on an iphone, but it just does not cut it for an actual PC game. You sit and wait for your potatoes to be done and you are occasionally thrown a random event which is a reference to an older game with two options which can both be a success (Minor, barely noticable effect on a single potatosmith), or a bad event which will give you a slight bad effect on a single potatosmith. In the end, you can just skip most of them and you wouldn't lose out on anything. It relies purely on it's 'humour' of gaming references and potato puns to be interesting, which does not make for a good game.

There is simply no gameplay to be had. No real managing your store, or figuring out what to do best, just telling your spuds to go do stuff and then waiting for them to do it. I would say it is closer to an interactive screensaver with pretense of being a game than it is to actually being a game - Sad too, as I was hoping to find a good management game

With a price of 15 euro, I would say it is severely overpricing itself. If it were in an app store, for maybe 5 euro/dollar I could see it succeed, but at this price and on a PC it has no chance at all. If you are still curious about it, pick it up at a sale, but don't bother with it full price unless you are a very patient person, and you do not mind not having anything to do.

Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?!
Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?! is an amazingly fun simulation and management game where you craft weapons for heroes. The game is full of numerous references to games, movies, and literature.  I will add a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
You are the grandson of the great blacksmith Batata and you are informed by Agent 46 that he has passed away. Agent 46 informs you that you now own 0.01% of the shop while he own 99.99% of the shop. You start off with 3 different smiths to help you out. Each smith you can hire is essentially a parody of one character or another. Hulk Hogan becomes Bulk Bogan and so on. Throughout the game you craft an enormous amount of different weapons for heroes. There are legendary heroes and smiths who most people will recognize. There are 4 main stats that your weapons will use which include Magic, Speed, Accuracy, and Attack. The smiths have expansions into classes which improve their stats at improving certain aspects of a weapon.  There are different regions to sell in and different heroes who will buy your weapons. The storyline is enjoyable and there are random events where you have to make a choice which will reward you or punish you. You can send your smiths to sell, shop, explore, train, and vacation. This is a game that will slowly make you want to play more and more with its interesting features.

Graphics/Sound
The graphics in the game are polished and smooth (you know for a potato). Each character resembles a potato while also having different unique features. The character design is uniquely potato-like and the little customization options are nice. The music adds to the enjoyment and relaxation in this game. The character sounds are cute to say the least.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Dozens references to movies, literature, and games
+ Dozens of weapons to forge
+ Class Tree
+ Simple yet enjoyable storyline
+ Batato (Batman is a potato)
+ Mood system and dog helping mood
+ Artwork
+ Legendary Heroes and Smiths
+ Can spend hours playing this game

Cons

- Can get repetitive
- Bit slow at first
- Not that much customization
- Can only send 3 smiths at once to one location at a time

Suggestions
These are my personal suggestions for the game. My suggestions do not need to be taken seriously as they are my personal opinion for hopefully adding to the game to make it more enjoyable.

- When doing a request with a certain prefix have some way of checking the request while selecting the prefix to make sure you get it right
- More customization for the shop

Final Thoughts
I am happy to have been able to play this game. The amount of references is insane and the characters are potatoes. I have played this game quite a bit and am happy to say I regret nothing. The game is highly enjoyable but also has a good design and story. I love all of the little things and parodies I saw in characters, items, contracts, and choices.

TL;DR
Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?! This game is full of references to gaming, literature, and movies. The story is solid and the gameplay is enjoyable. You start off with a simple shop with 3 smiths and soon you will have a shop with up to 10 smiths. There is a class tree for your smiths and 4 different stats which help your weapon like Magic, Attack, Speed, and Accuracy. While the shop customization is limited and the gameplay can become tedious at times the game is highly relaxing and has many fun features to create an enjoyable experience.

The art and animation is top notch, the plot sequences are enjoyable and sometimes funny, and the music is good. I was impressed again and again by the level of effort put into the UI, from the shop to the world map to the weapon selling screen. Little extras, like the confetti that appears when a smith brings money home, make cycling through the game menus a joy.

This is good, because you'll be doing a lot of menu cycling. Where the presentation is vibrant, the gameplay is fairly one-dimensional. The game consists almost entirely of menus to start and end tasks like selling weapons, exploring for materials, or going on vacation. The only visibility into what your exploring/buying/selling smiths are actually doing is a timer filling up over a thumbnail. Even the shop floor, where you can move (very adorable) blacksmiths to different stations to boost weapon stats during forging, feels very cut and dry. This one non-menu activity is also fairly clunky: the lack of a button to pause time combined with a left click to move and select control scheme feels like running underwater as you scramble to move your smiths between stations.

Despite the overall excellence of the menus, tooltips, thumbnails and maps that are, essentially, the gameplay, there were a few oversights that made for more needless work in the game. For instance, a great deal of time in the game is spent switching between your forging stations and the prospective buyers to see what stats they prefer, and what you can craft to satisfy their needs. Because there is no way to see buyer information from the forging stations, you must go through three menus to look at them. Eventually I just wrote down their stats on paper so I could see them in the forge.

I hate to say this, because this game clearly represents a substantial amount of work, and I honestly will look for the next game the studio puts out. Holy Potatoes comes in a beautiful package, but the gameplay lacks substance. While a fast forward button does help to cut down the waiting that mostly fills the spaces between menu clicks, the game unfortunately loses its novelty fairly quickly. If the game were cheaper, it could have been a good buy for the three hours of fun I had with it. At this price, I can't recommend it.

I'm not a big sim games player so I won't be able to compare it to other games in this genre. But so far, with 10 hours recorded on Steam (a bit more offline) I can say I'm enjoying it. It's colorful, it's cute and most of all it's full of humour and references to other games/movies/pop culture (Agent 46, Claude Strife, Nyandalf among others). And a potato-dog.

Despite its look, it's not a mobile game port, it was just made by people who worked on mobile games before. Then boosts and enchantments will allow you to make more powerful weapons with more freedom over the stats. Plus a dog to boost the morale of your blacksmiths and an assistant to boost a workshop (aka all blacksmiths assigned to a specific stat).

Holy Potatoes! What a Wonderful Game!

If you've ever played Game Dev Story, or similar Kairosoft titles, or Fiz (brewery) on mobile devices, you'll love this game. This is the type of game I've been keen to see on steam - a proper, fun simulation that involves a shop but no adventuring. Which is exactly what you get here.

The game starts as you inherit 0.01% of your grandfather's blacksmith shop and take over management of it. The tutorial is perfect, and funny - easily leading you through the basic steps of how to play - which is how to smith weapons, how to sell weapons (and who to sell to), how to buy materials and how to boost weapon stats. While you are locked to accessing 'noob village' at the start for buying and selling, there are other locations which will become available as you progress.

Graphically this game is lovely - it is very cute, and very unique. Think Cyanide & Happiness for how it looks. It is colourful, and easy on the eyes. It doesn't look cluttered and I was never lost for where to find anything. The menus are clear and the text easy to read.

The game plays with no issues, no bugs, no lags. The controls are excellent, and intuitive. There are 3 speed of play choices, and all are able to be used from the start. This means that there's no feeling of waiting on things to happen.

While I have referenced Kairosoft and similar titles - this games stands alone and apart from them - with random events happening throughout play (and breaking up the waiting while weapons are being forged) and phyiscally leaving the shop to buy and sell. Where this game is similar is in the mechanics of how staff function, and in boosting and in staff levelling. For anyone familar with similar titles, this will feel very comfortable and enjoyable.

10/10 :-)

reviewText:
* Key provided by Developer

In Holy Potatoes! you take on the role of a potato with a very, very long name whose grandfather has recently died, leaving you as inheritance 0.01% of his weapons shop. This is mainly a management game, your goal is to make weapons and sell them for profit, and there is a little story there to be told.

While the game might look like a mobile port, and the scarce menu might hint to it as well, Holy Potatoes! doesn’t have some of the annoyances other mobile and social type games have: namely the ‘friends’, the ‘coins’ that you buy with real money (at least, they aren’t there for now), nor the energy bar that restricts your playing. By all means, you’re free to grab the game for a five minute of five hours stretch without any lack-of-energy penalty.

What it does lack, and my biggest complaints with the whole thing, are things that the developers seem to be currently working on: A pause button, and the ability to put the game on windowed mode. That is, a windowed mode with more resolutions, for you can alt+enter but it remains at a ridiculously unnecessary large resolution as of current.

Holy Potatoes! has some funny dialogue, cutesy sound bites, ok button sounds, and background music that I personally found annoying enough to mute. The character designs are on the cutesy cartoony side, with some of them and some expressions being far cuter than others, but overall being fairly decent. There’s several references to pop culture (you even get famous adventurers come in to make requests from you) which make the game interesting and funny.

The game is fairly simple as far as management gameplay goes.You make use of the various menus to purchase or find items to make weapons with, and then you sell said weapons to adventurers. There is some depth to be had with this system: The adventurers you sell to actually level up thanks to your weapons, which brings you fame. The smiths are not locked to a single job station, your metal worker can become a designer who in turn can become a craftsman. This allows you to level up in more than one aspect, and as you level each smithing ability to max (5), you get to unlock further smithin abilities that will allow you to make stronger weapons.
As with every management type of game, you can enchant things, decorate and expand your shop, buy some items that will boost workers’ morale or abilities, etc. You can even send them on vacations when they get too depressed, which makes for a nice change of pace. There is also a nice weather system in place that affects the workers.

The only thing I found annoying with the system were the “random” encounters which happened a little too often (but I hear the devs are also working on it). Since you can choose up to two different speeds above normal to play it on, the interruptions of these random encounters become far more noticeable and terribly annoying: You’re not even done doing one thing that another one pops up. Still, they bring some nice boosts (money and smith stats) when you get them right, and some of them are also rather funny.

There are some things that could be better: like finding what weapons sell best where, or having more maps, etc.

The developers seem to be fairly active in listening to the users and working out the kinks of the game, which is always pretty amazing.

In its current state I would give this game a 6.5, going on 7/10 when they fix the pause and window mode issues. As far as management games go I would recommend this one as good game. I’m not certain, however, that I would recommend it for the full price unless there was more content added to it.

reviewText:
Holy Potatoes! A weapon shop! Is full of cute graphics, spud humor, and addicting gameplay for those who love the simulation genre.
It may seem at first to be a really repetitive experience, but the game keeps growing in depth.
You start out as a young potato learning that your grandfather has passed and you inherited his weapon shop. Well, you own 0.01 percent of his weapon shop. Who care, you have a cool new occupation, wait you don’t know anything about making weapons? No worries, blacksmiths do all the work. Blacksmiths like Lara Craft. Who knew a spud raider could be so perky?
Each blacksmith has a finely tuned skill they start off with and those create stats for weapons for “heroes” Yup, like bandits, pirates, gladiators, and snipers. Totally the hero type, if you know what I mean spud.
Each blacksmith’s specialty goes to an attribute. Attack power, Accuracy, Speed, and Magic. But as you progress, the game starts to open up, as you can upgrade your shop, hire more blacksmiths and work your blacksmiths skills until they master everything.  It takes time, training, but worth it. You’ll learn tricks along the way, learn which “heroes” like what weapons and what stats are within reach.  Take a look at the training tree, there are lots of reasons to re-assign job titles in order to become a weapons master. There are tons of little details in this game that shine, from random decision making about where or not to turn on a tv that is outside of your shop to saving kids from bullies, to random statues to put in the store, it’s quite the adventure.
Always be on the lookout for the annual weapon awards, here if you win, you get cash bonuses, and maybe get some starch into the judges hands for a little positivity in your direction. Yes, starch is really the currency, and yes, I LOVE IT!
Once you start gaining reputation Big time heroes start looking for you, they will request very specific weapons and give you lots of bonuses. Plus the interactions are hilarious and full of spud puns.
It’s a fun story, a well put together simulation game, and I found myself losing track of time while playing this game. I say it’s well worth the 14.99, and if you dig fun music, great artwork, and Lots of potato jokes, it’s a must have.

reviewText:
So basically you are a potato smith in a potato universe. You are taking over for your deceased grandfather, who was a great potato smith. You get to name your smith, and I being the creative person I am (sarcasm) named him potato. You own his 0.01% of the weapon shop. Agent supposedly owns the other 99.9% and he claims that your grandfather and he had made this deal. The following may be a spoiler: Agent seems reluctant to talk about himself, your grandfather, and the past. I haven’t finished the game yet but I’m suspicious of agent.

So anyway, your mission is to craft many weapons to sell to heroes around the universe. Each hero has a preference of the type of weapon and what stats he likes. There are four stats: attack, speed, accuracy, and magic. You can also research new weapons and that gives you the ability to craft that weapon. Once you move onto the next universe, you cannot research weapons in the previous universe, so I suggest you research all of them before moving on.
In the beginning, you start off with 3 employees. Later on you gain/hire more. The staff can gain experience for crafting, selling, and exploring and level up. Each member can boost a skill that they are assigned to. Once they reach max level, they won’t gain xp anymore and you have the option of changing their skill (attack, speed, accuracy, or magic).
The story line is really interesting and enjoying. The dialog is great. You know how some games you want to skip the dialog? This isn’t one of them. I really love all the puns and music references. I also love the characters’ personality. There are trivia and random events that keep the game engaging.

I think this game would make a good mobile game. It’s the kind of game I’d like to play on the go. If it were available for mobile or some other handheld device, I’ll get it right away.

The graphics are wonderful and clean. I love looking at it. And the colors are perfect. Not too bright or dark. I don’t know how to explain it but the graphics, colors, and game play are seriously wonderful.

I did have some trouble with lag and freezing, usually when I change areas (ie from shop to map) HOWEVER I’m not sure if it’s from the game itself or from my computer. And I’m really suspecting it’s from my end but I’m not 100% sure. But this doesn’t hinder the game or make it unplayable, and it sure isn’t a brother (not like dota lag/freeze). You can easily ignore it – it isn’t annoying or a pain.

In summary,

Graphics 10/10
Color 10/10
Story 10/10
Game play 10/10

If you love potatoes, puns, and making things this game is for you. Actually you should just get/try this game anyway lol. It’s really fun and addicting. I can play for a while without noticing the time go by. Especially since I have to have everything perfect and to completion, like researching all the weapons and getting every hero to max level before moving to the next universe.

It really looks like a lot of hard work has been put into this game.

Anyway, overall I give this game 10/10

reviewText:
This is a relaxing game, more easy and casual-friendly than milestones of the genre like Recettear.
The story is simple and dumb, but fun. Graphic and sound are top notch.
That said it's pretty clear that it's a parody with tons of references to more famous games like Half Life, FF and tons of anime and american series: it's a nice title to take a break from more complex games, nothing more and nothing less.

In-depth gameplay analysis:

Forging weapons is fun, but it tends to get pretty repetitive: you just need to assign the right smiths (statswise) to the right place and choose the best weapon type according your customer preferred stats and weapons and then basically wait for the weapon completion, gaining more money and fame by making heroes level up with your weapons.
Smiths gain exp and level up their classes, starting from a class specialized in only one of the four different stats (Atk, Mag, Spd, Acc) and progressively unlocking better classes specialized in more stats at once. During the game part of the challenge is managing your smiths' class change in order to not waste exp and cover every stat efficiently.
Comparing this to most of the management games I found that there is no economic pressure whatsoever because while the salary of your employees tends to increase quickly so do your gains and the shady agent 46 doesn't ask you money regularly, but just on certain events.
This, unfortunately, tends to be a lot more rewarding for the safe and slow grinding strategy (which I don't dislike) since you can gain a lot of money and a reasonable amount of exp by making and selling the same good weapons to the same heroes (even when they have reached max level) making you reach one of the two ultimate classes (the ones specialized in every stat) with most of your characters way before the endgame.
The game world is pretty simple, consisting of 4 stages with 3-6 different places each, some places can be explored by your employees to find relics and rare materials to research and craft new weapons, some can be used to buy basic materials, some can be used to train and some to send your stressed smiths on a vacation.
The training and vaction prices and events for each place change with the season, while the items for each place are always the same and follow a pretty linear tier progression meaning that the last area unlocked is probably the only one you need to keep exploring because it usually has strictly better items.
Your smiths can also level up their merchant and exploration skills providing more rewards from exploration and some extra cash and discount while selling/buying.
Your little shop can be improved by adding a variety of stat-boosting decorations and your smiths can gain temporary status effects that improve/lower some stats and there is also a prize to win each year for the best weapons crafted, these are minor aspects that are not very impactful gamewise, especially at the beginning, but are nice additions.

Overall Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?! is a good mix but tends to become easier and less complex the more you advance through the story, since having smiths that can do anything or a max lvl merchant pretty much takes away every hard micromanagement choice; however this is not intended to be an endless game so when you reach this point you can pretty much rush to the ending.

The game achievements are the standard ones: craft 25 daggers, craft 50 spears, do this quest that you probably need to do anyway to advance through the story (0 effort required), so they are bad and will require multiple playtroughs/some extra time spent on grinding.

PS If you find yourself liking the game and you want a challenge I recommend buying the DLC.

reviewText:
I began playing Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?!  a few days ago and have played for several hours. It is a fun and very addictive management game.

The beginning of the game is kind of slow as it is a tutorial area and nothing is unlocked. Now, I am sure there are people that will judge the game based on this beginning part and not give the game an actual chance. So, my first suggestion is to play through the tutorial part and get into the real gameplay where things start to unlock and the game really comes alive. The tutorial part of the game takes about half an hour or so to complete.

There are new abilities and options that are unlocked throughout the game. You get to research new weapons, unlock new areas to explore and also get new upgrades available to you.

There are 5 different types of smiths that work in your shop. They all work together to create great weapons. In the beginning there are only 3 smiths unlocked. Later on in the game, you unlock the 4th smith.

As you progress through the game, you will find various characters and side stories. There are also random events that start occurring. Some of these events will give you two choices to decide from. Your choice can have a positive or negative impact on your smiths or the weapons that they are working on.

The controls and gameplay in Holy Potatoes are very simple. This is a game that anyone can play very easily. Even if you have a slower system or limited resources, you will be able to play and enjoy this game.

This is a game that I would recommend to anyone that enjoys management games of any type. It is a game that is fun to play, has humor and comedy elements, and will definitely keep your attention for a long time. It is also a game that offers steam achievements.

reviewText:
This game deserves a solid recommendation. Those idiots who voted negtively obviously did not play the game enough to really appreciate it. Please guys, read the reviews carefully. Haters can hate elsewhere. This game deserves a thumbs up.

Serveral hours into the game so far and its has been a beautiful experience.
I was not sure at first but now i am utterly convinced.
The game doesnt only have a uniquely gorgeous art style, the simulation and management elements are well designed.
UI is well explained and I find it pretty easy to pick up.
But do not be fooled by its cartoony appearance, this proves to get more and more challenging as you peel away each layer. I am only 6 hours in and I am already amazed by the features that are slowly being unveiled every step I take into this game. I know there are some players who dislike references but I am totally enjoying the pop culture references in this game. It isnt the core that holds the game together but it adds a lovely element to this fundamentally solid game.

The save file bug was a messy one but the fact that the dev managed to fix it within 24 hours is quite a feat.
Furthermore, they have been super active in the discussions and picking up on any suggestions, feedback and bugs reported. After I noticed a recent post they put out in the discussions which was basically all the suggestions made by the players with concrete plans on how they will be addressing our concerns, i felt compelled to write a review.

Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?! isnt only a very solid title, it has an amazingly dedicated developer behind it. With this, you are assured that this great game can only get better.

Way to go, Devs! You are doing a great job.

This game has literally no progression, but on the other hand requires minimal thinking.
It could have been released as a phone game instead with this depth.
From the beginning you can craft 3 types of weapons; daggers, bows and axes. These are built up of values of 4 different attributes; attack, speed, accuracy (and magic, comes later).
The game revolves around smithing weapons of a certain type and attributes that a certain customer would want, for example a thief that requests a speedy dagger.
And that's it.

Pros:
Contains a lot of popular culture in names or dialogue.
Graphics are sweet
Was fun for a while when I was sick

Cons:

reviewText:
I got this game because DansGaming was playing it and it practically sucked me into buying it. There's a lot of positives to the game, but also a bit of cons as well. The game does well in maintaining a cute charm that blends in well with the story of a potato that inherits a weapon shop from his diseased grandfather. It's kind of like the story of early Harvest Moon games, except the mayor is replaced by a sneaky Agent 46 who claims to be a businessman..Or is he?

The game plays like many Kairosoft games, so there's that argument about it being a nice looking mobile game on steam. It definitely is one and you'll have to wait a certain amount of time for your weapons to finish and even longer if you're researching new weapons.

All your potatosmiths level up which allow them to make better quality weapons, or reduce the time of research. They also level up their merchant skills, which allow them to haggle for better prices. By leveling exploration, it allows your smiths to gather a lot more materials when they go on an exploration.

Each smith has 4 different stats that come into play as well. They are attack, magic, speed, and accuracy. Each warrior in the various regions have stat preferences and you'll have to cater to their needs if you decide to sell it to them. Unlike games such as Recettear, you can directly go to the warrior's location instead of relying on a little bit of RNG. Every smith has a stat that they may excel at and in the end, I let go of Bulk Bogan, because his stats weren't on par with some of the other smiths you can hire. Take care brother, you're a real american.

In order to progress through the game, you'll have to reach quotas that are displayed in the upper right hand corner. Your tasks for these quotas include gathering a certain amount of items, reaching a certain amount of fame, and paying Agent 46. It's a lot easier to do than you may think and sometimes, you'll find yourself nailing several tasks at once just because you've done a lot.

The story is quirky with tons of potato puns and game references. However, the game ends a bit abruptly, and I don't know if there's a way to get a better ending or not, because once I load my game, it goes to my last task and ends with the same little cutscene without letting me continue to play the game. There's no end game content here, which is kind of a bummer due to the price.

Another feature I didn't like was the lack of a pause button. I really felt it's needed in this game, or at least an auto pause after you decide your next move when you finish making a weapon or something.

Overall, it's a good game, a little pricy for what you get, but if you're into timewaster games, simulations, or just like puns, this game will be enjoyable.

Note: Devs are currently working on all of the things I complained about. :O

reviewText:
Management sims in a lot of ways live and die by their UI. How easily can I get the information needed to make a decision and how quickly can I implement a plan once I've made my choice? When done well a UI is something you never think about, a seamless extension of yourself. Other times it is like the UI of Holy Potatoes, a game I have to assume was ported from mobile devices due to UI design choices that make no sense otherwise.

But to back up a little bit and explain the big picture, in Holy Potatoes you run a blacksmith selling weapons to various questing heroes the likes of which most of us have played as in any number of RPG's. Your main currency beyond money is fame and fame is determined by how well heroes perform in the field while using the weapons you build. It's a decent concept for a game and there is a fair amount of depth later on as you manage 10 different smiths and their various needs. In the end though, Holy Potatoes is sunk by two key issues.

The first is difficulty. Simply put, the game is a cakewalk. You are presented with a series of missions to complete, one at a time by the game. Usually these involve increasing your fame or leveling up the heroes that hire you by giving them superior weapons. And occasionally the game asks you to hand over some money to the shady owner of your smithy. But there were times when I would complete an objective only to find the next three objectives were already completed. The best management sims show how difficult it is to balance the various parts of a major business, but even towards the end when the game becomes a bit hectic, I never came anywhere close to running out of money. And because there is no pressure there the entire game becomes a series of bars that need to be filled. And filling them is inevitable. The only thing making better weapons does is speed up the process.

But even an easy game can be fun for a while if the act of playing is enjoyable enough. Who doesn't love the occasional power trip or even a game where overcoming a challenge isn't nearly as important as making interesting narrative choices? But this game is neither of these things. For one the narrative choices you make don't seem to have any effect on the story progress, but more damning for a game this easy, you never get that sense of being all mighty because of an awful port job from the mobile version I'm just going to assume existed before this one.

I assume that because of the ridiculous way certain aspects of the game are designed. A key example occurs when you send out a smith to buy more components to make more weapons. You'd expect a menu to pop up that let you type in how much you want of each component but as far as I can tell there is no typing in numbers here. Nor can you hold down a button to have a number increase at a rising speed. No, to buy each and every item you must click on a button over and over, turning something that should be an automated process into tedium. I should be able to tell some smith under me to replace certain resources whenever my stockpiles drop below a certain level. I should be able to research multiple new weapons at once. I shouldn't have to click on an icon every time a smith returns from a job just to put him back where I left him.

Holy Potatoes is a game with potential and I'm curious to see if the recently announced sequel lives up to that potential. In the here and now, though, realize that this game barely qualifies as a management sim, considering how little actual managing you do.

Decent art design and audio work make the game easy to look at and listen to, but the referential humor is just lazy and none of it hides how many key features this self proclaimed management sim is lacking.

reviewText:
Take the customer and shop aspects of Recettear, add the managing aspects of both Game Dev Story and the various time management games like Diner Dash, blend in a lot of humor. Now shape it into a universe full of Potato people, bake it, and then drown it in puns, references, and silliness.

And you might get something like Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?!. That, or a grand ol tasty mess.

Holy Potatoes jackets you with picking up the legacy of your grandfather, the ol spud. Once a renowned blacksmith, you begin rebuilding the family legacy as you hire a variety of blacksmiths for your shop to create weapons. Each blacksmith starts good at a specific weapon stat (attack, speed, accuracy), and they work together to forge a weapon.  Send your smiths out to sell weapons and buy supplies at various towns and dangerous areas. Have them explore and locate rare materials you'll need to research new weapons. Send them out on vacation to relax, as a stressed smith is a bad smith!

You earn $tarch, the world's currency, which you need to pay your blacksmiths, pay rent, buy supplies, do research, and upgrade your shop. A smith can only do one thing at a time, so you need to balance making weapons, selling them, researching, and many other things. Various events will effect both your smiths and your weapons.

Overall, the game is extremely fun and humorous. It doesn't rely on references and humor to be a fantastic game at its core, but it definitely helps.

If you can't stand a sack of puns, though, you might avoid it.

reviewText:
Holy Potatoes is a fun and relaxing game with a number of good running gags and one-off jokes. The gameplay is largely based upon resource management, requiring you to assign your workers to different tasks effectively and focus on training them in the right areas.

The early game presents a challenge to use your resources and people efficiently, but by mid- to late-game it's easy to be so overpowered that you don't need to care about efficiency or pay attention to details. DLC is supposed to up the challenge in the game, but the first available DLC was not actually much harder than the base story.

I realize that's not a ringing endorsement, but on the whole, I'd recommend the game if you like casual resource management games.

As the game progresses you have a lot of managing to do. Sending your workers to explore for materials, traveling to the different towns to sell your wares, and researching better weapons. Oh and forging incredible legendary items for the bravest of heroes and adventurers.

There's a lot of depth in this game and I'm excited to see what else is in store! Also, there's a potato dog!

reviewText:
Super cute and a super relaxing gameplay.
I'm writing this review for my curator group as i wanted to let everyone in my curator group know this fantastic game.
In this time management you are in charge of your own weapon shop, you work together with several weapon specialists such as magic, attack, speed and even more.
You can craft several sorts of weapons and you have tons of weapon variants per weapon category, you can research new weapons aswell.

Every character has it's own skills and you can train them by letting them earn experience while crafting and selling weapons, there are also quests you can complete on your road to the best and obviously holy weapon shop in the world of potato heroes.
I'm amazed by the positiveness of this game, it can make each of us pretty happy while playing.

Let's continue to the ratings:
--- Positive points ---

Cute and polished top notch indie graphics
Great controls for a management game
Performance is great even at low end laptops and PC's
The music is one of the most amazing parts of this game, really motivating
Steam trading cards support, that means backgrounds and cute emoticons aswell
Steam achievements
No bugs, at least i haven't found any
Thanks to more DLC there is replayability aswell
Decent price tag
Addictive gameplay that motivates you everytime for playing more
--- Negative points ---

They could have added more achievements, like 200+ as that motivates the player/achievement hunter even more
Workshop & Gameplay:
In my opinion would workshop support be nice for all of us, people could create more quests for each other and the community activity could be increased.
Most single player games without workshop or other community-activity increasing elements have a lack of activity on the forums and community hub, they could motivate people by adding workshop support.
Also new decorations and other props could be created by the community this way, as it's a single player game, all mods would be compatible in main gameplay.

Summary:
This game is a hidden gem for most of us, it's not popular in the steam store as it's almost never goes on sale and you don't find it on a quick steam search ( except if your search for this game of course ) .
People should be able to play this game as a demo first before buying so they can experience that this game is actually worth it.
There are so many time management games especially in this indie genre, so people should be able to test the game first before they hand out their money.
This game in a nutshell: Great graphics, addicting gameplay and motivating music for a decent price tag.

Happy questing !

Holy Potatoes is my newest game but it quickly ended up as my favorite. In fact I like it so much that I just have to post this review because I can only recommend it.

The gameplay follows a simple idea, the player owns a blacksmith shop and forges weapons for heroes who gain experience and tell their mom, friends and cat about the store which in turn leads to new shop upgrades, customers and regions. It’s easy to get into but the difficulty does increase with the shop level and failure can occur. Holy Potatoes had me hooked from the beginning and I might be a tiny bit addicted to it already.

I haven’t completed the game yet but so far I’m very intrigued by the plot, the story is quirky and funny but also has some serious moments. The art style is very unique; clear lines and bright colors make the game easy on the eyes and convey a happy atmosphere at the same time. Although there is no voice acting emotions are clearly shown through the expressions and sounds the characters have and they make them extremely likeable.

It’s nice to look at and a lot of fun to play, I recommend it to anyone looking for a relaxing, well-made management game.

reviewText:
A pretty simple store management game where you make and sell weapons. Decent graphics, a basic story to tie things together and full of pop/gaming culture references.

You start out with access to one area that has a few customers that want to buy your weapons. These customers are static and always want a certain type of weapon with certain stats. When you make a weapon, you choose what stats to give it by moving your smiths around to one of the four stations. There's a station for each stat: attack, accuracy, speed and magic (I learned them as red, blue, green and yellow because stats have no difference to you). The higher the stat a weapon has, the more money it sells for and the more XP the customer gets.

You can make new weapons by researching them (which consumes relics and uses a smith) and the new weapons usually have better stat growths, which leads to higher sale prices and customer XP.

Once I understood the mechanics it wasn't too hard to start a new game, follow the pattern/procedure I wanted, and repeat until everything was completed and I jumped ahead of the difficulty curve.

You don't want smiths to gain unused levels because it also increases their wages (at least until you have too much money to know what to do with it). I picked one person to be my dedicated explorer and another to be my dedicated salesperson. Also, to keep wages in check, I didn't upgrade the class of my explorer (because they were on constant exploration duty).

The simplest flow is to create batches of 3 weapons for customers in the same area then send your merchant to sell them all at once.

Eventually, everything flowed smoothly and the money came flowing in. My explorer gave me the materials, relics and enchantments needed to make great weapons, the weapons sold for a lot of money, and the money was used to pay for maintenance, upgrades and as a money buffer for the next world.

Other notes:
Make sure to complete the objectives at the top-right of the screen. They're necessary to advance the plot and unlock new areas.
As far as I can tell, there isn't any reason to rush to the next world so make sure to save enough money before entering the next world. You'll use the money to buy upgrades.
If you're ahead of the difficulty curve, contracts and random requests are generally a waste of time because they don't give customer XP. However, if you're in dire need of cash they're a decent way to get that little extra to pay your smiths at the end of the month.
When you input the razer promo code for the weapon, you might want to be in a certain world (probably the final world) because I used the code right away and couldn't research it, possibly because I didn't have access to the later-tier relics. It didn't let me research it in the later worlds and I couldn't input the code again.
Worth a look if you like clickers and store-management/stat maximizing games.

reviewText:
TL:DR a good idea for a game but it got too grindy and boring after a couple of hours and started to feel like work

This is a pretty simple tycoon style game that is heavily influenced by Game Dev Tycoon. Instead of being a game studio making games, you have a weapon shop where you make weapons and everybody is a potato for some reason. You have four workstations and each has a different focus, being strength,accuracy,speed and magic. You assign your workers to the station that matches their skills, pick a weapon to craft and then craft it. Then you send one of them off to sell the crafted weapons. Thats pretty much the majority of the gameplay.

There are other things to do with your workers like send them off to explore the different available areas for materials and send them on holiday or training but the bulk of it is just crafting weapons. While the game is fun for the first hour or two it turns into a massive grind later on where it just becomes a process of researching and crafting weapons to sell to get your profits and fame up. As theres little else to do, that quickly gets really boring. It just got to a point where I couldnt take the repetitive grind anymore and stopped playing.

Good points:
-the game looks pretty good with its cute cartoon graphics and they fit the game quite well
-the game at least has a wide variety of weapons to research and craft

Bad points:
- the gameplay is just too repetitive and gets very grindy later on. It started to feel more like work than a fun game to play.
-I didnt really like the games humour and with all the pop culture references and memes it feels a bit forced
- this game feels like it would be better suited as a mobile game than a PC game
